MC	<p>fbb3_6490</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>ceeb_ce8b</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene J</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>a062_35a4</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>5161_261c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene P</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>11c9_ccee</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene N</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>06ac_4c76</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene H</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>29d8_2ed4</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene C</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes C and K</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>7369_9577</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene T</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>6974_ee3f</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>d2da_8767</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>ff43_eeaf</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene M</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>17bc_c5be</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene A</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>0c35_a318</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes B and X</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>4f56_ab50</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene N</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>ead5_5e52</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene W</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>86ae_186c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene R</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>818e_ca16</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene F</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>0278_18c0</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene P</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>06ed_90ee</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>632a_98e9</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>5c18_5fbb</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene P</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene R</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>e7d2_711c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes D and Y</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>9e13_f95c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene M</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; MC	<p>2a34_bf14</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene K</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene Y</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. MC	<p>a7f2_4973</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>0ca3_8d9e</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene N</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes N and W</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene M</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene P</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes M and P</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>e3e0_396e</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>a979_be10</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>51d5_b77b</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>c208_50af</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>26f9_c4bf</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene K</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>82d5_f332</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene J</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes J and N</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>feaa_8de1</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene K</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; display: inline-table; vertical-align: middle;"> <tr><td style="border-bottom: 1px solid black; text-align: center;">1,248</td></tr> <tr><td style="text-align: center;">4,000</td></tr></table> = 0.3120 = <strong>31.20 cM</strong>	Correct
MC	<p>1115_361e</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene K</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. MC	<p>cd34_56d4</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene J</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene C</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene M</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>983d_43f5</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene H</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. MC	<p>61a4_3127</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene C</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene R</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>2821_ef54</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene F</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>c6ae_2384</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>73fd_a3d5</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene A</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>66bf_9f1b</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes A and X</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>1080_40bb</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene M</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene R</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; MC	<p>b4cc_90f0</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>b02d_7bd9</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene K</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>knotted</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene K</span> cells grow in twisted, coiled shapes, resulting in a knotted or gnarled appearance.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. MC	<p>c8bf_08f2</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes N and W</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>e125_e586</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes C and P</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>a900_6582</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>c1e7_ec6c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>f9c0_8522</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>53af_732d</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>0803_2388</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>8858_395d</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse;
