NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes C and W</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>54b9_7ad4</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene J</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>96d3_564c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene J</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>jeweled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene J</span> colonies appear dotted with tiny, iridescent spots that sparkle under light.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes H and J</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>b81b_d79c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>bubbly</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene B</span> produces excessive gas bubbles during growth, causing foamy appearance of the media.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene T</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>4440_fc27</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene T</span> secretes a toxic compound that inhibits or kills other microbial colonies nearby.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>c4fb_adcd</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes F and X</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>7293_0b2c</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>69a4_38a0</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene H</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>c1b7_3ff5</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>2c94_6ed7</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>doubled</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene M</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>2eae_bfdd</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes F and W</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>4ca6_fb05</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>elephant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span> cells absorb excessive amounts of liquid, resulting in giant, swollen cells.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px; display: inline-table; vertical-align: middle;"> <tr><td style="border-bottom: 1px solid black; text-align: center;">&half;(2,986) + 3&times;(96)</td></tr> <tr><td style="text-align: center;">8,200</td></tr></table> = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; display: inline-table; vertical-align: middle;"> <tr><td style="border-bottom: 1px solid black; text-align: center;">1,781</td></tr> <tr><td style="text-align: center;">8,200</td></tr></table> = 0.2172 = <strong>21.72 cM</strong>	Correct
MC	<p>58d2_fe02</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>14e1_ca08</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span> colonies are covered in soft, fine filaments, giving them a fuzzy, cotton-like texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene D</span> cells display double or multiple budding, with several buds emerging simultaneously.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>toxic</i></span>' phenotype. MC	<p>abe3_6535</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>nude</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene N</span> cells have an unusually smooth surface with no visible external features or textures.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene P</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>pebble</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene P</span> produces colonies with a rough, uneven surface that resembles a collection of tiny pebbles.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes N and P</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene A</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>amber</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene A</span> cells develop a rich yellow-orange pigmentation, giving the colony a warm, amber hue.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>hairy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene H</span> cells develop long, thread-like filaments that extend outward, creating a hairy, shaggy texture on the colony.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; font-family: monospace;">a</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 0px;"><span style="font-size: large; font-family: monospace; color: #008000;">+</span></td></tr></table></div></span></td> <td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">5,750</span></td></tr><tr> <th colspan="5" align="right" style="border: 1px solid black;">TOTAL =</th> <td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black;">9,200</td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Step-by-Step Instructions</h6><ul> <li>Step 1: Find the row for the Parental Type for all three genes.</li> <li>Step 2: Looking at only your two genes, assign PD, NPD, TT.</li> <li>Step 3: Determine if the two genes are linked.</li> <ul><li>PD &gt;&gt; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes A and H</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>37e6_e7f6</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>militant</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span> colonies are small, dense, and secrete compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby colonies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene X</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>xenon</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene X</span> cells emit a faint glow under UV light, as if they were fluorescent.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene R</span> colonies develop a reddish-brown pigmentation, reminiscent of rusted metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>webbed</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> colonies produce delicate, web-like strands that connect neighboring colonies in a cobweb pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; NPD &rarr; linked; PD &approx; NPD &rarr; unlinked</li></ul> <li>Step 4: Determine the map distance between the two genes.</li> <ul><li>D = &half; (TT + 6 NPD) / total = (3 NPD + &half; TT) / total</li></ul></ul><h5>Determine the distance between the two genes R and W</h5>	A. distance = <table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>5709_93fa</p> <h5>Unordered Tetrad Two Gene Mapping</h5><p>In this problem, you will use unordered tetrads to determine the between a single pair of genes and calculate the distances between them. The yeast <i>Saccharomyces cerevisiae</i> is used in this study. A cross has been performed to study the linkage relationships among two genes, and the resulting genotypes are summarized in the table below.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene C</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>clumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene C</span> grows in dense, irregular clusters, with cells clumping together rather than spreading smoothly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yolk</i></span>' phenotype. A budding yeast that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> cells develop a dense, yellowish core that resembles an egg yolk when viewed under a microscope.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black; width: 400px; height: 220px;"><tr> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Set #</th> <th colspan="4" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Tetrad Genotypes</th> <th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;">Progeny<br/>Count</th></tr><tr> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1</span></td> <td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><div style="padding-left: 5px;
